{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3063068,"name":"Kevin - 247 Assistant Coach/Alumni","username":"berkleyfanatic","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/berkleyfanatic/{size}/268552_2.png","created_at":"2022-05-18T23:42:31.244Z","cooked":"

Hello CD, I am a mentor of FRC 247 Da Bears from Berkley MI, We are approaching our summer and want to look into creating a swerve drive for the 2023 season and beyond. We are primarily looking to 3D print our own parts and want to know what teams recommend. We love our two speed transmissions and our defensive capability but want to move into a different direction. If teams have recommendations on where to start for 3D printing our own or how to do so please let me know. Thank you all!

Designs from @Nick_Coussens are great inspiration. Although I would probably make changes to better fit our needs there is a lot to like from these designs. I have wondered whether max spline could be used to make it work like the SDS modules with the double gear and steering encoder.

Coussens 2021 Fall Swerve General Forum
[COUSSENS 2021 FALL SWERVE ISO 1] [COUSSENS 2021 FALL SWERVE ISO 2] [COUSSENS 2021 FALL SWERVE TOP] [COUSSENS 2021 FALL SWERVE SECTION] The latest iteration of my swerve design. previous versions and more information on previous development can be found here. STEP and SolidWorks files available here. Bill of Materials can be found here. Main changes on this version were the following: Replaced the Lamprey Encoder with the REV Through Bore Encoder. This was to improve reliability and ha…
2021 Winter Swerve General Forum
[21WS_NC ISO 1] [21WS_NC ISO 2] The latest iteration of my swerve design. Previous versions and more information on previous development can be found here. STEP and SolidWorks files available here. Main change on this version from the last is I made it longer to be able to make it shorter by moving the Ultraplanetary and NEO 550 out and down so that it is less exposed and to make the module shorter overall. 3.875 W x 5.25 L x 7.6 H 3.25lbs All gearing of the drive and steering is the sam…

While I can’t give it a personal recommendation, this thread has a fairly low-cost option: GBX-173, $160 low-resource swerve module

Best of luck! Getting the mechanical complexity of a swerve drive handled during the summer is a great way to get started, and is a key building block to having a successful robot on top of that swerve drive.

I’ve since improved on the design in GBX-175 and 177:
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/7ca227110e30a2ac2a0ce07b/w/75ba66e36ad16d28fa38053d/e/b0af3116f45aa6ff0e4ce803

https://cad.onshape.com/documents/a96881ff0655a6507e86e267/w/74ed98b9bf6da36558723fc8/e/c752e6696d403c5653d6baf1

There’s still a lot of testing to do on GBX-177 - I might have to change a lot of the top part of the structure due to belt rubbing - but the finished product should be lighter, smaller, and even a little bit cheaper. Plus it’s all in Onshape so it’s easier to share and modify. I have BOMs available for both upon request.

If you do make it let me know - I’d love to fix up any problems with the design and assembly process.

BOM for GBX-177: GBX-177 AliswerveV3 BOM - Google Sheets
